paragraphs.text: Buffalo schools spend $5.4 million on free plastic surgeries for teachers, despite massive deficit.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: BUFFALO, N.Y  - Even a $50 million budget deficit in the Buffalo school district couldn't convince members of the Buffalo Federation of Teachers to cut down on their taxpayer-funded tummy tucks, breast lifts and nose jobs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In fact
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: school district spending on the unique benefit, known as a "cosmetic rider" on the insurance plan for union members, totaled $5.4 million in 2013-14, an increase of 4.1 percent from 2012-2013 and an increase of 9.5 percent from two years ago, according to public records information obtained exclusively by EAGnews
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: As an indication of just how much the perk is being utilized, according to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons, the average cost of rhinoplasty is $4,545, while the average cost of liposuction is $2,866
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: A breast lift costs $4,207, on average
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: In other words
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: over 1,200 Buffalo teachers union members could have had a boob job last year, at taxpayer expense
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The annual expenditure is staggering, given the district's troubled financial situation, not to mention its sketchy academic performance
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In January 2014, the Buffalo News reported that the school district was grappling with a $50 million budget deficit for the 2013-14 school year
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "That gives us very little wiggle room to fund anything new," Barbara Smith, the district's chief financial officer, told the school board
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Except, of course, for a lot of new cosmetic medical procedures for teachers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The "cosmetic rider" benefit has been offered to teachers for decades and has been scrutinized only recently due to the school district's financial plight
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The school board has been unwilling to impose a new labor agreement without the rider, as allowed by law
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So the district has been operating under the terms of an old agreement - which includes the cosmetic rider- that expired about 10 years ago
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Until the union agrees to a new contract without the perk, the school district will continue paying
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That possibility has been discussed for years
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the union has never budged
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "There's no co-pay (for cosmetic procedures), so the school district ends up footing the entire bill," The Atlantic reported in 2012
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Perhaps if the Buffalo school district produced great academic results, and students who were prepared for college or the working world upon graduation, taxpayers could justify such a cushy benefit for teachers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But that's clearly not the case
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The district recently boasted that its graduation rate improved from a miserable 47.8 percent to 56 percent
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: So slightly more than half of the students are now getting a diploma
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which is hardly a reason to celebrate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The district's latest student proficiency numbers are ugly, as well
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to the Buffalo News, only 12.2 percent of Buffalo students rated proficient or better on recent standardized English tests
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: while only 13.1 percent rated proficient or better in math
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: So what has this teaching staff accomplished that merits a benefit as costly and wasteful as free cosmetic surgery?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The June 2014 union newsletter - appropriately named The Provocator - includes ads from three cosmetic service providers pedaling procedures like Botox, cosmetic breast and body contouring, facelifts, hair transplantation, and "medispa" treatments
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Those ads are bound to pay off for the providers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because the teachers can obtain their pricey services for free
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - at our expense, of course
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There is a chance that the cosmetic rider could finally be abolished through labor negotiations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Most recently
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: an outside mediator proposed giving teachers an 11.8 percent pay increase
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: in exchange they would pay a "small" amount toward their own health insurance
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The proposal also calls for ending the plastic surgery coverage, according to the Buffalo News
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: While completely eliminating the "cosmetic rider" from its benefits package would not plug the $50 million budget hole
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the annual expense is an indication that the school board is not serious about reining in out of control spending, nor making sure every dollar is going directly towards the education of children
paragraphs.label: assumption
